Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Has does one go about making a CPU rig?  Just a bunch of multi CPU motherboards and associated CPU ?  Anything else to it?

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: a "CPU rig" is nothing more than a "bare bones" PC

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Ok simple enough,  wasn't sure if there was something more to it

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @polycryptoblog i have a fancy mobo + CPU sitting on a piece of cardboard box, no case of any kind, wires everywhere, mining VRSC

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢 is that "bare bones" ?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: for efficiency of capital costs, I think recent laptops win out

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: except for the "fancy mobo" bit :trollface:

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but maybe CG has some crazy math research to dump on us

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yeah, i could have spent less on mobo, i spent like $150 instead of $90ish

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i am not doing this at scale

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i mine VRSC on 3 laptops and 4 desktop/servers

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: solo mining since the olden 384 times

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i am often surprised which machines outperform others

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Yes, is it better to go completely barebones with consumer desktop/laptop is the hash from server CPUs comparable or better than the desktop CPU ?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: laptop get better watt per hash

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: lower power costs per coin, it works out to

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: laptops also take up way less space

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: And easier resell value

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: make sure to account that even tiny compact "lunchbox" desktops need to have a monitor/keyboard connected for maintenance (which always fucking happens)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: VRSC has had so many mandatory upgrades

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: those old library "thin" desktops are the shiznizzle

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but laptops don't need to have monitors and laptops within cable distance/etc, they are less maintenance in that respect

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am a tiny miner, but I see that the time you spend maintaining rigs is the biggest "hidden cost" that almost nobody accounts for

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I rented time on beefy AWS boxen for VRSC, when that was a reasonable thing to do. nethash is basically too high for AWS prices now

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if you find something that is viable, let me know 😃

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: That's why I went asic ,  just interested in spreading out into other kinds of mining.     I think CPU /GPU will have a place still in the future ,  I'm surprised no one has done a BOINC based system with a proper business model . I think we will see it in the kmd ecosystem in the next couple of years

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Right now I only have ASICs and CPU VRSC miners warming me, I like diversifying into both instead of being "all-in" with one or the other

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: each allow for different opportunities

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I have a few old ati radeon 58xx GPUs that mined BTC back in the day, wondering what they can pull in VerusHash now

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: What I hear is that there will be "blood on the streets" next month when ETH block reward goes from 3 to 2, and those ETH miners will scatter their 1080ti's to the winds of all the altcoins in weird places

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: raising them hashrates, to the tears of many a hobby miner

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Yes it's already starting can find 1080 at like 400 1080ti at 550

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: one of them places they go is VRSC

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: would I pay $500 for a GPU right now, a used one, to mine VRSC? That is a hard question

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i mined a ridiculous amount of VRSC, that is timelocked, in the 384 block days, so my perspective is warped. But VRSC is at something like 35 cents now. Not sure the math works out to buy the GPU

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but if you have it already

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it makes a lot of sense to point it at VRSC

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I'm considering getting the vega gpus they are going pretty cheap and its replacement isn't coming out anytime soon

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i really know nothing about GPU mining VRSC, I have always done CPU solo from the beginning. It's hard to keep track of

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i5/i7's are the sweet spot for cost/hash it seems, and I like CPU mining for some reason

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: has anybody done tests comparing a VRSC full node miner to ccminer on the same machine? https://github.com/monkins1010/ccminer/releases

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i am hearing people saying they get way higher hashrate on ccminer, not just some small %

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: or compared against nheqminer

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am seeing a 25% hashrate increase in ccminer over vrsc full node, shaking my head

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: not sure I can trust those numbers, so I will collect more data

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 50% hashrate increase? Am I dreaming?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ccminer vs vrsc full node mining has a ~65% hashrate improvement, same hardware. quite the tax on the solo miner
